what.title: 什么是 clr.fund?
what.paragraph: Clr.fund, 发音为 "Clear Fund", 是一个协议，旨在根据以太坊社区的偏好，将资金有效地分配给对以太坊网络有益的公共产品。 Clr.fund 致力于可信的中立性、去中心化、无需许可、信任和匿名性。

why.title: 为什么 clr.fund 存在?
why.paragraph-1-text-2: ——既不可排除又不可减少的商品或服务——对于任何生态系统来说都是一个挑战，以太坊也不例外。
why.paragraph-2: Clr.fund 的目标是使资金能够分配给对以太坊网络有益的公共商品，而无需依赖中央实体，并且以反映以太坊社区偏好的方式。
why.paragraph-3-text-2: 去了解有关 Clr.fund 的目标和价值观的更多细节

unique.title: clr.fund 有何独特?
unique.paragraph-1: Clr.fund 的实例还具有许多其他特殊属性：
unique.li-1-text-1: 去中心化——Clr.fund 的基础设施的主要部分都建立在
unique.li-1-text-2: 上，以太坊是一个可编程的区块链，为 Clr.fund 的投票和资金交易提供可靠的、免受审查的分类账。
unique.li-1-link-2: 请参阅更多关于 Clr.fund 的去中心化。
unique.li-2-text-1: 可扩展性——由于使用以太坊对用户来说可能很昂贵，因此 Clr.fund 使用
unique.li-2-text-2: 来获得主以太坊网络的大部分优势，但交易更快、更便宜。
unique.li-2-link-1: 请参阅更多关于 Clr.fund 使用第 2 层的信息。
unique.li-3-text-1: 防止结盟——由于区块链, 如以太坊, 公开发布所有数据, Clr.fund 的贡献者容易受到贿赂和其他形式的操纵。因此 clr.fund 使用被称为零知识证明的神奇数学来防止这些攻击。
unique.li-3-link-1: MACI 是我们的最小反结盟基础设施。
unique.li-4-text-1: 防止 Sybil 攻击——投票结果有相对利益的投票系统, 如 quadratic funding, 容易受到 sybil 攻击, 即一个人建立许多身份来多次投票。 Clr.fund 通过 BrightID 的身份系统来减轻这种威胁。
unique.li-4-link-1: 请参阅更多关于 BrightID 的信息。
unique.paragraph-2: Clr.fund 也是特别建造，以便任何人都可以启动运行自己公共产品拨款的项目。

how.title: 它是如何运作的？
how.paragraph-1-text-1: Clr.fund 使用约束性自由激进主义 (CLR)，通常称为
how.paragraph-1-text-2: (QF), 以促进社区成员对以太坊公共货物建设者的货币贡献。
how.paragraph-2: 凭借以太坊 smart contracts 和其他 web3 技术, clr.fund 对任何个人或实体的信任要求特低，并且对结盟和贿赂具有弹性。
how.paragraph-3: 从高层面的视角看, clr.fund 由一个匹配池和一个筹款回合组成。慈善个人或组织贡献匹配池。匹配池的资金是以社区偏好分配。 捐赠者直接捐款于他们重视的项目, 因此为该项目获得一部份匹配池的份额，有效地的增加了捐赠者的贡献价值。
how.paragraph-4-text-2: 的零知识证明 (ZK-SNARKS), 以保护个人贡献的隐私，并限制勾结和贿赂的有效性。
how.paragraph-5: 为了确保每位贡献者都是独特的, clr.fund使用

heading.title: Contributor guide
heading.paragraph: An overview of how things work as a contributor so you can learn what to expect throughout the duration of a funding round.

funds.title: Get funds on {chain}
funds.paragraph-1-text-1: You'll need some {currency} on {chain} in order to submit transactions to the clr.fund smart contracts.
funds.paragraph-3-link-1: Read our explanation on how clr.fund uses layer 2 on Ethereum.

contributing.title: Contributing to specific projects
contributing.li-1-text-1: Before contributing to specific projects, you will need to
contributing.li-1-link-1: verify that you're a unique human
contributing.li-2: Make sure you have {nativeTokenSymbol} in your BrightID-verified wallet on the {chain} network
contributing.li-3-text: and add some to your cart, adjusting your contributions to the amount of {nativeTokenSymbol} you want.
contributing.li-4: When you're ready, open your cart, click contribute, and confirm the transactions to complete your contributions!
contributing.paragraph: Note: you can only contribute once. After submitting your contributions, you can reallocate them as much as you would like before of the reallocation phase but you cannot add more funds to your total contribution amount.
contributing.li-5: You can add and remove projects.
contributing.li-6: Your reallocation total must be less than or equal to the total (if it's less, the rest will go to the matching pool).

matching.title: Contributing to the matching pool
matching.paragraph-text-1: Not sure which specific to contribute to? Contributions to the matching pool will be distributed to all projects that receive project-specific contributions during that round. The weighting of this distribution is determined by the
matching.li-1: First make sure the wallet you are using holds {nativeTokenSymbol} on {chain}. {nativeTokenSymbol} can be easily purchased on any major Ethereum-focused exchange.
matching.li-2-text-1: Once you have the desired amount of {nativeTokenSymbol} in your wallet, select "Add Funds" on the

wow.title: How does clr.fund work
wow.paragraph: Looking for a more general overview?
wow.link: Check out our "clr.fund 是如何运作" 页面

heading.title: Decentralization in Clr.fund
heading.subtitle: What is Decentralization?
heading.paragraph: When we say something is "decentralized" in clr.fund, and in web3 broadly, we mean that no single person, company, or other entity is solely responsible for running or maintaining it. Instead, a decentralized system is run or maintained by a large group of independent entities, coordinated by a set of rules each opts into, like miners in Ethereum or peers in BitTorrent.

which.title: Which pieces of clr.fund are decentralized?
which.paragraph-1: Much of clr.fund's infrastructure is built on Ethereum, a decentralized blockchain:
which.li-1: the registry of projects qualified for funding (and, potentially, the curation mechanism for choosing these projects)
which.li-3: the sybil-resistant registry of users qualified to contribute to individual projects
which.li-4: the funds from and encrypted information about contributions to individual projects
which.li-5: the mechanism for distributing funds once a round's results are finalized
which.exists_in_code: Each of these pieces exists in an Ethereum smart contract (see the code
which.maintained_by_miner: , meaning its functionality is maintained by Ethereum miners, a decentralized group.

why.title: Why is clr.fund decentralized?
why.paragraph: Ethereum's decentralization provides clr.fund with three main benefits:
why.li-1: Transparent process — All of the decentralized pieces of clr.fund are publicly verifiable. Anyone can look at the code for the smart contracts and observe its inputs and outputs, with very little possibility that anything is being hidden or changed secretly.
why.li-2-text-1: Secure voting — Because of Ethereum's strong security guarantees, anyone submitting a message can be extremely confident that their message will be processed as expected by the system. There are still security dangers, of course, such as
why.li-2-text-3: , but the kind of "vote hacking" typically feared in digital voting is highly unlikely here.
why.li-3-text-1: Public good — Everything on Ethereum is open source and permissionless, which means the code for clr.fund's decentralized infrastructure acts as a public good: anyone can deploy their own version of the system to create their own
why.li-3-text-2: system, with the same decentralized benefits of the original.

heading.title: 这个筹款回合是如何运作的
heading.subtitle: CLR 入门教程
heading.paragraph-1: 这是一个概述帮助您了解整个筹款期间您可以期望什么。
heading.paragraph-2: 如果您正在寻找如何参与的指南，可以查看我们专门为捐赠者和项目成员提供的指南。

quick.title: 回顾 quadratic funding
quick.paragraph-1-text-2: 的概述, 项目将会从个人捐赠和捐赠池中获得资金。当你捐赠你最喜欢的项目时，你的捐赠也会被视为一票。项目获得的捐赠数量越多，它就会获得越多的票数。而项目获得的票数越多，它从捐赠池中获得的资金就越多。尽管个人捐赠金额越高，投票权重就越大，但拥有大量独特捐赠的项目要比拥有少量高额捐赠的项目更重要。
quick.paragraph-2: 由于这次资金筹集也是一场公开投票，因此需要设定截止时间。整个筹款轮次分为多个阶段，这样在所有捐赠或投票完成后，就可以在最终的捐赠池分配之前对它们进行计数和确认。这样的设计有助于保证筹款活动的公平性和公正性。

phases.title: 筹款阶段
phases.subtitle: 加入阶段
phases.paragraph-1-text-1: 为了开启筹款轮次，将会邀请项目参加
phases.paragraph-1-text-2: 。如果你是一名热心的捐赠者，你可以浏览这些项目并添加它们到你的捐赠购物车中，但你还不能对它们进行捐赠。这个阶段的目的是为了让捐赠者能够更好地了解这些项目，并做好捐赠的准备。

need.title: 了解事项
need.li-1: 本次筹款轮次的项目数量将会有上限，最多可以有 {maxRecipients} 个项目参与。
need.li-2-text: 所有想要参与本次筹款轮次的项目都必须符合筹款轮次的一些
need.li-3-text: 如果你想要参与本次筹款，现在是最好时机

contribution.title: 贡献阶段
contribution.paragraph-1: 筹款正式启动，你可以捐赠你喜欢的项目了

need.title: 了解事项
need.li-1: 这个阶段将持续 {contributionPhaseDays} 天。
need.li-4: 一旦你完成了捐赠，你的捐赠总额就是最终的。你不能再次捐赠来增加你的总捐赠额。

contribution.paragraph-2: 如果你在捐赠阶段没有捐赠，那么一旦这个阶段结束，你就不能再参与本轮筹款了。

reallocation.title: 调整阶段
reallocation.paragraph: 在这个阶段，如果你已经捐赠了，你将有时间改变主意。你可以编辑你的捐赠金额或添加/删除项目，但你的总捐赠额必须等于你原来的捐赠额。

need.title: 了解事项
need.li-1: 在捐赠阶段结束后，这个阶段将持续 {reallocationPhaseDays} 天。
need.li-2: 如果你删除了某些项目，你必须将这些资金重新分配给其他项目，否则它将被捐赠到匹配池中。
need.li-3: 你在重新分配资金时不能超过你原来的总捐赠额。

tallying.title: 统计阶段
tallying.paragraph-text-1: 在这个阶段, 所有的捐款都是最终的，现在可以进行统计。筹款负责人会触发
tallying.paragraph-text-2: 和 smart contract, 计算每个项目将获得多少匹配池的份额。

finalized.title: 最终阶段
finalized.paragraph: 一旦统计完成，筹款就结束了。项目所有者可以来申领他们的捐款！

more.title: 更多
more.paragraph: 我们使用不同的技术来确保筹款的公平性, 并防止恶意行为。您可以在下面了解更多相关信息：
more.li-1-text: - 防止贿赂行为，并确保筹款结果。

heading.title: 关于二层网络
heading.subtitle: Clr.fund 在二层网络
heading.paragraph-1-text-2: 上运行，以帮助您节省时间和金钱为您喜欢的项目做出贡献。 您需要一个在 {chain} 上有资金的钱包来应用此程序。

transactions.title: 以太坊交易成本
transactions.paragraph-1: 以太坊是包含clr.fund大部分基础设施的区块链, 要求用户在与它交互时支付交易成本，并且这些成本正在上升。 交易费用补偿了以太坊矿工的分散社区，以便安全处理和维护区块链的状态。 随着以太坊的使用量的增加，矿工包含您的交易在区块链上的价格也随之增加。
transactions.paragraph-2: 使用以太坊的成本上升表明它是有用的, 这是很好的, 但它也给不想支付10美元或100美元的费用的最终用户带来了问题。

scalability.title: 可扩展性的第二层网络
scalability.p1: 以太坊区块链，"第一层网络", 可能会升级以降低未来的成本 (这是clr.fund正在帮助实现的以太坊未来目标之一)。
scalability.p2: 但是, 在短期内, "第二层网络" 解决方案已经帮助大幅降低成本。 大多数第2层是 "rollup", 区块链类似的系统，由分散的节点群维护。 Rollup 定期将其所有最近的交易 "滚动" 到记录在第一层网络 Ethereum 上的单个交易中，从而继承了以太坊的大部分安全性。
scalability.p3: 第二层上的交易比第一层便宜数量级, 因为 rollup 可以处理大量交易和交易流量现在被分散在许多第二层选项中。

arbitrum.p1: 第2层rollup方法有许多变体。 Clr.fund 使用 {chain}，一种 "乐观" 风格的 rollup。
arbitrum.link: 在 {chain} 文档中了解更多信息。
arbitrum.subtitle: 您需要什么
arbitrum.h3: 💼 如何找到支持 {chain} 的钱包
arbitrum.tooltip: 钱包资源作为一种方便提供，不代表其中任何项目或服务的认可。 始终要DYOR。
arbitrum.li3_t2: , 并按 "钱包" 进行筛选, 查看当前支持 {chain} 网络的一些钱包。
arbitrum.li4_t1: 再次检查您考虑的任何钱包是否还支持
arbitrum.li4_t2: 以确保您能够连接到应用程序。

funds.h3: 💰 如何在 {chain} 上获得资金
funds.p1_t1: 按照下面的步骤操作，或者随时使用
funds.li1: 点击上面转到官方的 {chain} 桥接器
funds.li3: 选择货币（先把一些 ETH 用于燃气，再把一些 {nativeTokenSymbol} 用于贡献)
funds.li3_p: 对于 {nativeTokenSymbol}，单击 "Token" 菜单, 搜索 {nativeTokenSymbol} 并选择"Token"
funds.p2_t1: 一旦您将 {nativeTokenSymbol} 桥接到了 {chain}，您可能会想在 MetaMask 中将

what.p1: tl;dr: 恐吓或贿赂者无法成功（不会成功）。
what.p2: Clr.fund 采用 MACI (最小反合作基础设施）来防止投票操纵，例如贿赂或合作。要理解为什么这很重要，我们来复习一下 quadratic funding...

quadratic.p1: 这是clr.fund在资金轮中使用的机制。当您为项目提供资金时, 您不仅在向他们提供资金，还在为他们投票。最后，匹配池资金将根据轮次结束时的投票数量分配给项目。
quadratic.p3: 这种机制对于民主基金很好，但也存在一些风险。项目负责人可能会花费很少的代价来贿赂用户投票支持他们的项目，因为最终的匹配池金额可能会非常高。这种欺诈方式会使整个概念面临风险，因为它不再是关于哪些项目为最多人提供最多价值的问题。

background.p1: 投票操纵涉及恶意改变投票系统的激励机制，包括：
background.li1: 操纵选票——当一个人或实体提供支付给他人投票支持一个结果，他们本来可能不会这样做，例如支付一支足球队丢掉一场比赛
background.li2: 强迫——当一个人或实体威胁惩罚其他人如果他们不投票给特定的结果，例如敲诈勒索
background.p2: 这些操纵破坏了投票系统，使它们背离了原本的目标。投票系统通常被设计用来发现集团对多个指定结果的偏好。每个选民都应该根据他们更喜欢的结果和他们的投票如何影响结果来选择如何投票。
background.p3: 在选举中, 如果结果是1) 爱丽丝胜利和2) 鲍勃胜利, 如果我更喜欢爱丽丝胜利并且认为我的投票有足够高的机会影响结果值得费心, 我会投票给爱丽丝。现在, 假设查理提供给我1,000,000美元投票给鲍勃。对于我来说, 选举的可能结果现在变成了1)爱丽丝胜利和2)鲍勃胜利,我会得到1,000,000美元。在这种情况下,即使我更喜欢爱丽丝，我也可能会投票给鲍勃，选举结果将不再反映我对鲍勃和爱丽丝的偏好，如本来打算的那样。如果足够多的人成功受到贿赂，选举将是一场恶作剧。

vulnerability.h3: 公共投票系统的脆弱性
vulnerability.p1: 为了操纵特定投票者的结果，操纵者需要知道该投票者最终的选择: 如果查理提供给我100万美元投票给鲍勃, 他需要知道我实际上会投票给鲍勃, 然后才付给我钱。否则, 我可以投票给爱丽丝, 告诉查理我投了鲍勃, 得到100万美元, 贿赂就失败了。
vulnerability.p2: 传统选举中，投票是秘密的，很难操纵投票者。但是以太坊上没有任何秘密！在以太坊上的大多数现有投票系统中，投票是公开的，这意味着操纵是一个严重威胁。

why.p1: 以太坊是clr.fund和其他 quadratic funding 解决方案 (如Gitcoin Grants) 的核心部分，因为：
why.li1: 以太坊拥有较低的基础设施成本和较高的安全性（即难以被黑客攻击），相比其他电子投票解决方案而言
why.li2: 以太坊具有与越来越多的社区和工具的无缝互操作性，这些社区和工具可以增强和受益于 quadratic funding 的管理, 如DAO和BrightID等身份系统
why.li3: clr.fund是由以太坊社区建立的, 为以太坊社区服务。
why.p2: 不利用以太坊的公开特性不是一个好的选择, 但是建立工具来抵抗投票操纵是可行的, 这就带我们来到了MACI。

helps.p1: 只有当贿赂者可以确认他们支付的人实际上遵守了贿赂的条件，贿赂才会有效。这就是 MACI 的用武之地。通过 MACI, 不可能证明你是如何投票的，所以贿赂者永远不会知道你是否按照他们的要求行事。
helps.h2_2: MACI - 最小反合作基础设施
helps.p2: MACI 是一组以太坊智能合约和补充脚本，可以有效地将公共投票系统转换为私有投票系统，其中 1) 投票参与和投票计票公开可验证，但 2）特定投票信息不公开，使投票操纵更加困难。

how.p1: 当您在 clr.fund 上向一个项目贡献时，您会向轮次协调员注册一个身份。但在轮次结束前的任何时崎，您都可以通过在投票前秘密更改与您的身份相关联的公钥来使您的身份无效。您可以使用另一对密钥对投票进行签名(这使得投票无效，但无法看到投票是否无效)。
how.p2: MACI 通过零知识证明来实现这一点。这些数学证明了投票的真实性，但没有提供任何细节。因此，行贿者无法确定他们行贿的人采取了什么行动。
how.p4: 白名单选民 Alice、Bob 和 Charlie 通过将公钥发送到智能合约注册投票。此外，还有一个中央协调员 Dave, 他的公钥是众所共知的。
how.p5: 当Alice投票时, 她会用私钥对投票进行签名, 用Dave的公钥对签名进行加密, 并将结果提交到智能合约。
how.p6: 每个选民都可以随时更改她的密钥对。为此，她创建和签署一个密钥更改命令，将其加密，并将其发送到智能合约。这使得贿赂者永远无法确定他们的贿赂是否对贿赂对象的投票产生了任何影响。
how.p7: 如果鲍勃 (Bob) 为了某种方式贿赂了爱丽丝 (Alice), 那么她可以简单地使用她注册的第一个公钥 (现在无效) 来投票。由于该投票是加密的, 就像爱丽丝之前发送给戴夫 (Dave) 的更改密钥消息一样，鲍勃没有办法确定爱丽丝是否确实投了他想要的票。
how.p8: 即使爱丽丝向鲍勃揭露了她的投票明文，她只需不展示她此前用来使该密钥无效的更新后的密钥命令即可。简而言之，只要她在投票之前提交了一条加密命令，就没有办法判断该投票是否有效。
how.link: 详细了解 MACI 的技术细节，请参阅此处。

constraints.p: 该技术处于前沿，目前存在一些限制。
constraints.li1: 目前这项技术有一些容量限制。这意味着，如果这个回合达到了容量，您可能会错过，但要知道，这是为了回合的完整性。
constraints.li2: 您每个回合只能捐赠一次。一旦您捐赠后，您可以添加/删除项目并重新分配资金，但您无法增加总捐赠金额。

more.l1: Vitalik Buterin on Minimal anti-collusion infrastructure

heading.p1: The first thing to understand about 'public goods' is that fundamentally, they are fully non-excludable and non-subtractable goods — a public good can be from the intangibles (i.e. knowledge) to the tangible social public goods (i.e. street lighting).
heading.p2: In economics, public goods are goods that are both:
heading.li1: Non-excludable — no one (who is a member of the "public") can be prevented from using the good, for any reason.
heading.li2: Non-rivalrous — one person using the good does not reduce anyone else's ability to use it.
heading.p3: Clean air, national security (for a given country), and free, open-source software (FOSS) are all examples of public goods, with FOSS being the most important for clr.fund.
heading.p4_t2: for a more specific description and context.

why.h2: Why create new funding mechanisms for public goods?
why.p1: Public goods are often underfunded because of something called the free rider problem: since public goods are always free and accessible for members of the public, people have little reason to contribute to their creation and maintenance. Instead, they can choose to be "free riders": using the public good but depending on others to build and maintain it.
why.p2: The free rider problem is quite present in open-source software, which is chronically underfunded despite being a core component of nearly all popular software products today.
why.p3: Clr.fund is an attempt to address the free rider problem for the Ethereum community, with the hope that this infrastructure may be useful for other publics in the future. By design, the funding rounds on clr.fund seek to involve members of the public from inception, and are allocating both decision making power and the exponential power to increase funding via the

heading.p1: Clr.fund is an implementation of quadratic funding, also called CLR (Capital-constrained Liberal Radicalism). Quadratic funding is made up of:
heading.li1: a pool of funds to be distributed
heading.li2: a voting system for distributing those funds
heading.p2: Two common voting systems you may have used are 1-person-1-vote and 1-dollar-1-vote. Quadratic funding is a best-of-both-worlds solution where users vote with the square root of the money they spend — read on to learn more.

problems.p1: The common fund-distribution systems of today all have pluses and minuses:
problems.p2: Markets can be thought of as fund-distributors: sellers are the fund recipients, and buyers are the voters deciding what will be funded. In this case, the "voting system" is 1-dollar-1-vote: each buyer has exactly as much potential influence over where funds go as they have money to spend. This is also the case for traditional crowdfunding platforms like Kickstarter.
problems.p3: An advantage of this system is that each voter's influence is directly proportional to their need (at least, if we ignore wealth inequality). The more Alice needs pizza, the more pizza she'll buy, and the more funding will go to pizzerias.
problems.p4: The disadvantage is that rich voters have an outsize influence on what gets funded. Alice may need pizza exactly as much as Bob needs movie tickets, but if Bob is twice as wealthy as Alice, he has twice as many "votes" to spend on going to the movies.

private.p1: Privately-owned grant-giving institutions, like non-profit foundations, are quite common, but they don't have voting systems. Instead, grants committees and the like solicit grant proposals and then choose which applicants will receive funding internally.
private.p2: An advantage of non-profits is that their non-profit status binds them to **act in the interest of some public mission**, rather than seeking profit above all.
private.p3: On the other hand, the small, private interests that control these organizations lack the tools and incentives to effectively serve large publics.

democratic.p1: Government grants are another common fund-distribution mechanism, and in democracies, these are usually controlled by voting citizens using 1-person-1-vote policies (with elected representatives and other middlemen in between).
democratic.p2: On the good side, these systems are much less oligarchical than markets—if we ignore the ability to convert money into influence via the media, among other complications.
democratic.p3: In exchange for less oligarchy, though, influence also poorly reflects need in 1-person-1-vote systems. A half-time Florida resident has the same voting power in Florida elections as a full-time resident, as long as both qualify to vote, even though the full-time resident may have twice as much riding on the result.

balance.p1: Quadratic funding is a compromise between 1-dollar-1-vote and 1-person-1-vote. Participants vote on how to distribute pooled funds by making individual donations, but each person's influence, rather than being the amount of money they spend, is the square root of that amount.
balance.p2: Compared to 1-dollar-1-vote in the market, quadratic funding makes it exponentially easier for the influence of many poorer people to outweigh that of a single rich person:
balance.li1: 1-dollar-1-vote: 1 person paying $10,000 has the same influence as 100 people paying $100
balance.li2: Quadratic funding: 1 person paying $10,000 has the same influence as 100 people paying $1 or 10 people paying $100
balance.p3: Compared to 1-person-1-vote, quadratic funding lets the person who lives in Florida full-time, and cares twice as much about the vote's outcome than the person who lives in Florida half-time, have more influence:
balance.li3: 1-person-1-vote: the two Florida voters have equal influence
balance.li4: Quadratic funding: the full-time Florida resident, who cares twice as much, pays twice as much, and as a result gets 2^(1/2) times the influence of the half-time resident
balance.p4: (It's important to note that while these example are a good demonstration of the argument for quadratic funding, they do over-simplify these situations, which are as sociological as they are mathematical.)

resources.li2: Liberal Radicalism: A Flexible Design For Philanthropic Matching Funds

heading.p: An overview of how things work as a recipient so you can learn what to expect throughout the duration of a funding round.

funds.p1: You'll need some {currency} on {chain} in order to submit transactions to the clr.fund smart contracts.
funds.link2: Read our explanation on how clr.fund uses layer 2 on Ethereum.

register.p1: In order to participate in a funding round as a project, you'll need to submit an application to join the recipient registry (via an on-chain transaction).
register.p2_t1: MACI, our anti-bribery tech, currently limits the amount of projects allowed per round.
register.p2_t2: . The round only accepts a total of {maxRecipients} projects, so we encourage you to apply early.
register.p3: Note: all application data (except contact email address) will be publicly stored on-chain.
register.li2: Click "See round criteria" and familiarize yourself with the criteria for projects.
register.li3: Once you're familiar with the criteria and you're sure your project meets them, click "Add project." You'll see a series of forms to fill out asking for more information about your project.
register.li4: With the forms finished, you can finish your submission:
register.li5: Connect to the right network via your wallet of choice.
register.li6: Send a transaction (with a deposit of {depositAmount} {depositToken}) to the registry contract.
register.p4: Projects are accepted by default, but the registry admin may remove projects that don't meet the criteria.
register.p5: In any case, your {depositToken} will be returned once your application has been either accepted or denied. Note that metadata pointing to all your project information (but not contact information) will be stored publicly on-chain.

claim.p: After a clr.fund round is finished, it's simple to claim your project's share of the funding. Return to your project's page: you will see a "claim funds" button if your project received contributions during the round. Submit the claim transaction to receive your funds.

how.p: Looking for a more general overview?
how.link: Check out our "How It Works" page

heading.p1_t1: "Sybil 攻击" 是指一个人假装成许多人来推翻系统规则。系统依赖于每个参与者是一个单独的人的程度越高, 就越容易受到 Sybil 攻击的威胁。社交媒体有一定的脆弱性: 机器人创建的电子邮件垃圾邮件和假的跟随或喜欢是相对无害的 Sybil 攻击的例子。数字投票系统更容易受到攻击: 如果攻击者能够创建足够的假用户来推动一次投票, 那么会有重大而实际的后果。因为 clr.fund 使用了
heading.p1_t2: , 它本质上是一个投票系统, 所以 Sybil 攻击是一个严重的威胁。
heading.p2: 在现实世界中, Sybil攻击很难实施。 假装成其他人很长时间是很难的, 特别是当大多数政府颁发和检查照片ID和ID号码时。在互联网上，没有人知道你是一只狗。人们不想在网上分享个人信息, 而政府身份证对无国界网络服务来说也是不切实际的，所以历史上我们没有强有力的方案去阻止网上 Sybil 攻击。

brightID.p1: BrightID 是我们用来增加对您只贡献一次的信心的平台。BrightID是一类新的数字身份解决方案之一. Clr.fund 用 BrightID 是因为需要 Sybil 抗性。
brightID.p2: 用户将他们的 BrightID 帐户与他们信任的独特人类相连接 (通常因为他们亲自认识他们）并形成团体。 这些连接是公开的，但用户的个人数据不是。 如果您将 BrightID 连接到应用程序，则应用程序可以分析您的连接并根据您可能是独特人员的可能性来决定是否允许您访问。 BrightID 连接的图可以使用任何方法进行分析, 但通常来说, 与其他可靠的 ID 的连接越多, 它就越可靠。
brightID.p3: 为了参与 clr.fund 回合中的项目, 您必须将已验证的 BrightID 与 clr.fund 应用程序连接。 这样可以防止您创建1000个以太坊帐户并扭曲贡献。
brightID.link: 按照这里的说明进行验证

how.p1_t2: , 以下是您可以期望的快速查看：
how.li2: 在 BrightID 中获得验证，以便我们知道您是人类而不是机器人
how.li3_t1: 提交一个区块链交易以便clr.fund为您提供 BrightID 赞助
how.li4: 将钱包链接到 BrightID 个人资料，以便您无法使用多个以太坊地址来影响投票
how.li5_t1: 将自己添加到 clr.fund 用户注册表中。 这是我们反贿赂技术

heading.p: BrightID verification helps prove that you’re a unique human. To get verified, you need enough people to confirm they've met you and you're a real person. There are a couple of ways to do this:

fastest.content: BrightID run verification parties regularly. Join the call, meet other new users, and they'll verify you’re a human and not a bot. Quick and painless, even for you introverts out there.

brightIDSponsor.p: You need a sponsorship token to become BrightID verified. This helps support BrightID as a decentralized platform. You’ll only ever need to do this once and it covers you for any other app that works with BrightID. Check the BrightID mobile app to see if you're sponsored. If you're not, click the button below to submit a sponsorship request.

brightIDSponsored.subtitle: You’re almost ready to contribute to your favorite projects! If you're verified for BrightID, link your wallet to your BrightID profile and start contributing.

callout.title: 参加资金轮次

how.title: 每笔捐款都会被匹配池放大。
how.paragraph: 这个筹款活动奖励那些拥有最独特社区需求的项目，而不仅仅是那些拥有最富裕支持者的项目。
how.subtitle: 如何运作

req.title: 您需要什么
req.chain: {chain} 用于快速和便宜的交易费
req.bright: BrightID 用于私有，去中心化的身份验证

about.title: 关于
about.paragraph-1: 在这个筹款活动中，我们使用 quadratic funding 模型来支持项目。这意味着，每当您向某个项目进行捐款时，您的贡献就会被视为对该项目的一票支持。最后，我们将根据每个项目所获得的支持票数来分配匹配池基金。这意味着，即使您的捐款金额很小，也可能对您支持的项目产生重大影响。
about.paragraph-2: 我们使用一种叫做 MACI 的零知识技术来防止贿赂, 这样可以确保每一笔捐款都是匿名的，无法证明您的贡献。这使贿赂者疯狂，因为他们不知道您是否真的做了他们贿赂您做的事情！
about.paragraph-3: clr.fund 是一个协议，旨在有效地分配资金给以太坊网络受益的公共商品， 根据以太坊社区的偏好。
